facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 165 of 1953 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1950, of the former Travancore Cochin High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 165 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1950, of the former Travancore Cochin High Court in A. S. No. 288 of 1120 T  arising out of the judgment and order dated the 3rd Thulum 1120 of the 2nd Judge, District Court, Quilon in C.M.P. No. 2391 dated 15-8-1103 in I.P. 3/1100.

facts.text: Usufructuary mortgage Ex. I for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924, executed by heirs of Koya Kunju to appellant's father.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the companycurrent orders of the Courts below allowing the Official Receivers application under s. 35 of Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090   1915 , to which we shall refer in the companyrse of this judgment as the Insolvency Regulation, for annulling the usufructuary mortgage  Ex. I  for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924, executed by a number of persons who may number be companyveniently described as the insolvents.

facts.text: Koya Kunju died in or about the year 1921 leaving widow, two sons and two daughters who carried on the ancestral business.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the arguments in this appeal it is necessary to state the following facts. Koya Kunju was a flourishing merchant at Quilon carrying on trade in piece goods, yarn, provisions etc. He died in or about the year 1921 leaving him surviving his widow, two sons and two daughters, who jointly carried on the ancestral business through the eldest son under a power of attorney.

facts.text: In June-July 1924, the sons approached the appellant's father, a money-lender at Mankompu, to advance Rs. 75,000 on usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: They added to the family business a tile factory and an oil mill. In June-July 1924 the sons approached the appellants father, who was a flourishing money-lender living about fifty to sixty miles away from Quilon at a place called Mankompu. He agreed to advance the sum of Rs. 75,000 on the usufructuary mortgage of certain immovable properties in and near Quilon belonging to the family, for the purpose of carrying on their trade and business after his two sons had made certain enquiries at Quilon about the status and means of the borrowers and whether the transaction would be worth their while.

facts.text: Mortgage bond and lease deed executed and registered on August 18, 1924, by heirs of Koya Kunju.

anchor.surface_text: After a draft had been made at the instance of the creditor, the mortgage bond and a lease deed granting a lease of the mortgaged properties to the mortgagors themselves bearing the same date, namely, August 18, 1924, were executed and registered by the heirs aforesaid.said of Koya Kunju. The purpose of the loan is stated in the document to be the family necessity, namely, carrying on trade etc.

facts.text: Mortgaged properties were unencumbered at the date of the transaction on August 18, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the mortgaged properties were unencumbered at the date of the transaction, but soon after a hypothecation deed in favour of a third party named Kadir Moideen Rowther was executed on August 30, 1924, for the sum of Rs. 78,859-15-0, hypothecating the equity of redemption in respect of the properties mortgaged to the appellant and certain other properties.

facts.text: Hypothecation bond executed on August 30, 1924, for Rs. 78,859-15-0 to Kadir Moideen Rowther.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the mortgaged properties were unencumbered at the date of the transaction, but soon after a hypothecation deed in favour of a third party named Kadir Moideen Rowther was executed on August 30, 1924, for the sum of Rs. 78,859-15-0, hypothecating the equity of redemption in respect of the properties mortgaged to the appellant and certain other properties.

facts.text: Insolvency application filed by S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther on September 15, 1924, against the five heirs of Koya Kunju.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1924, one of the business creditors of the family of the mortgagors,S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther, made an application in the District Court of Quilon for adjudicating them as insolvents. He implement the mortgagors, the five heirs aforesaid of Koya Kunju.

facts.text: Heirs adjudged insolvents by District Judge on August 29, 1927.

anchor.surface_text: All those proceedings appear to have been companysolidated and the District Judge by his orders dated August 29, 1927, adjudged the companynter petitioners insolvents.

facts.text: Official Receiver appointed interim receiver on October 19, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: By his orders dated October 19, 1924, the District Judge appointed the Official Receiver as the interim receiver in respect of the insolvents properties to take immediate possession thereof.

facts.text: Official Receiver applied on March 28, 1928, to annul the usufructuary mortgage and hypothecation bond under s.35 and 36.

anchor.surface_text: It was on March 28, 1928, that the Official Receiver made his application to the companyrt praying that the companyrt may be pleased to declare the transfers described in schedule A, void as against your petitioner. Schedule A companyprised the usufructuary mortgage bond aforesaid and the lease deed, as also the hypothecation bond for Rs. 78,859-15-0.

facts.text: District Judge allowed Official Receiver's application on October 19, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The annulment proceedings companymenced in 1928 and were determined by the Court of first instance by its orders dated October 19, 1944, For a period of more than sixteen years the annulment proceedings were kept hanging.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal, holding transaction not in good faith.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the mortgagee, the learned Judges of the High Court dis- agreed with the trial Judge and held that the decision in Mahomed Siddique YOUSUFs case  1  companyld number stand in the way of the appellant and that the entire companysideration of Rs. 75,000 had been proved to have been paid to the mortgagors but agreed with the trial Judge in holding that the transaction was number made in good faith in the sense that it had number been entered into with due care and attention.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 24, 1957 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957, May 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-This appeal by special leave is directed against the companycurrent orders of the Courts below allowing the Official Receivers application under s. 35 of Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090   1915 ,

facts.text: Full consideration of Rs. 75,000 was paid by mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: Though the learned District Judge held that only Rs. 20,000 had been paid by the mortgagee to the insolvents and Rs. 55,000 out of Rs. 75,000, the stated amount of the mortgage money, had remained unpaid, the High Court has found that the entire companysideration passed.

facts.text: District Judge found only Rs. 20,000 paid, but High Court found full Rs. 75,000 paid.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held on the merits that Ex. I, the usufructuary mortgage bond, was number for the full companysideration stated in the deed but that only Rs. 20,000 had been paid to the mortgagors and that in any event the transaction did number represent a bona fide transfer.

facts.text: Transaction held bona fide by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that the evidence adduced by the mortgagee apart from the question of burden of proof has affirmatively proved the passing of companysideration for the mortgage and that there are numbercircumstances which companyld throw any suspicion on the bona fides of the transaction.

facts.text: Mortgagee was a complete stranger to the mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection it has to be remembered that it is companymon ground that the mortgagee had absolutely numberhing to do with the mortgagors before the mortgage transaction was companycluded.

facts.text: Mortgagee's sons made enquiries at Quilon about borrowers' status.

anchor.surface_text: Before advancing this large sum of money the creditor had deputed his two advocate sons, C.P. Ws. 1 and 2, to make enquiries into the antecedents of the persons who had applied for the loan and as to whether they were financially sound and otherwise desirable persons to deal with.

facts.text: Rs. 55,000 paid in cash on August 20, 1924, remaining Rs. 20,000 in instalments September 1-9, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The father and the two sons have given evidence in support of their case that out of the Rs. 75,000 agreed to be advanced on the mortgage when some of the mortgagors went with the registered document to the mortgagees place, Rs. 55,000 was paid in cash to them on the basis of the receipt  Ex. LIV  dated August 20, 1924.

facts.text: Interim receiver reported on February 11, 1925, that mortgaged properties yield Rs. 1,600 per year.

anchor.surface_text: The interim receiver, Sri V. N. Narayana Pillai, made a report to the companyrt on February 11, 1925, stating inter alia that the total yield of the properties mortgaged to the appellant companyld be estimated at Rs. 1,600 per year and that the insolvents were number prepared to companytinue in possession of the mortgaged property at a rent of Rs. 6,750 as stipulated in the lease deed aforesaid.

facts.text: Mortgagee instituted suit for arrears of rent and possession, decreed.

anchor.surface_text: The rent having fallen in arrears over two years, the mortgagee instituted a suit against the mortgagors, impleading the Official Receiver also for recovery of arrears of rent with interest, as also for recovery of possession of the mortgaged property and the suit appears to have been decreed for the reliefs prayed for.

facts.text: First counter petitioner admitted debts including mortgage amount to two and a half lakhs, assets seven lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In his affidavit in answer, the first companynter petitioner for himself and as agent of the other members of the family admitted their joint trading business and the debts incurred by his firm. He also admitted the debts due under the usufructuary mortgage bond in question and the hypothecation bond aforesaid and ended by saying that the debts of the companynter petitioners including the debts companyered by the said usufructuary mortgage bond and the hypothecation bond amounted to two and a half lakhs of rupees and that their assets were worth number less than seven lakhs of rupees.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds burden of proof on Official Receiver to show lack of good faith and consideration.

anchor.surface_text: A number of points were raised on behalf of the appellant and at the threshold of the arguments it was companytended, and in our opinion rightly, that the companyrts below had erred in throwing the burden on the transferee of proving affirmatively that the transaction impeached, namely, the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18, 1924, was supported by good faith and valuable companysideration.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, mortgage binding on insolvents' estate.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the companyrts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents.

arguments.claim: Transaction within third exception to s.35: good faith and valuable consideration

anchor.surface_text: The main question for determination in this appeal on behalf of the transferee is whether the transaction in his favour is within the third exception to s. 35 aforesaid.  In this judgment we shall use the dates with reference to the Gregorian Calendar

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ther indication of the apparent solvency of the family. But it has been argued on behalf of the respondent that the mortgagee was put on his enquiry b

holdings.text: The order of adjudication is not res judicata on the question of good faith and valuable consideration of the usufructuary mortgage as there was no finding on the transferee's bona fides or lack of consideration, and the transferee was not a party to the adjudication proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, there is no finding that the transferee was privy to such acts. It was not necessary to find at that stage, and it has not in terms been found, that the transaction impugned in this case was not bona fide so far as the transferee is concerned or without consideration matters which directly arise for determination in the annulment proceedings leading up to this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adjudication found acts of insolvency by transferor but no finding on transferee's knowledge or consideration; transferee not party; even if PTIA s.116(2) applied, does not bar s.35 inquiry.

holdings.text: The initial burden of proof lies on the Official Receiver to show that the transaction was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: A number of points were raised on behalf of the appellant and at the threshold of the arguments it was contended, and in our opinion rightly, that the courts below had erred in throwing the burden on the transferee of proving affirmatively that the transaction impeached, namely, the usufructuary mortgage bond dated August 18, 1924, was supported by good faith and valuable consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Privy Council precedents (Khoo Saw Cheow, Chettyar Firm, Pope v. Official Assignee): settled law that burden on assignee/receiver seeking to annul.

holdings.text: The entire consideration of Rs. 75,000 passed to the mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: Though the learned District Judge held that only Rs. 20,000 had been paid by the mortgagee to the insolvents and Rs. 55,000 out of Rs. 75,000, the stated amount of the mortgage money, had remained unpaid, the High Court has found that the entire consideration passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluminous evidence (receipts Exs. LIV-LXXII, accounts, third-party creditors C.P.Ws. 3,4,9); Receiver failed to disprove; late denial unbelievable; affirms High Court.

holdings.text: In insolvency annulment under s.35, good faith means honesty (done honestly, even if negligent), not 'due care and attention'; Travancore General Clauses Act definition repugnant to insolvency context; Indian General Clauses Act test applies.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these considerations, in our opinion, the test of honesty is more appropriate than the test of due care and attention. ... It must, therefore, be held that the test of good faith as laid down in the law generally applicable to Indian Statutes is more appropriate to proceedings under the insolvency law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: insolvency protects honest creditors/business; due care test repugnant (saves negligent honest lenders); General Clauses saving clause 'unless repugnant'; favors Indian def. over Travancore.

holdings.text: The usufructuary mortgage was made in good faith (honesty) and for valuable consideration; Receiver failed to prove otherwise; transaction within third exception to s.35, not void against receiver.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that the evidence adduced by the mortgagee apart from the question of burden of proof has affirmatively proved the passing of consideration for the mortgage and that there are no circumstances which could throw any suspicion on the bona fides of the transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proved consideration (h3); mortgagee stranger, no collusion, enquiries made, no knowledge of insolvency; honesty test satisfied; resolves main issue.

holdings.text: Even assuming due care and attention test applies, mortgagee satisfied it: deputed sons for enquiries, properties unencumbered, borrowers reputed solvent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative application of lower courts' test: sufficient care shown despite no obligation to verify accounts/creditors list in business loan.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; judgments below set aside; usufructuary mortgage and lease binding on insolvents' estate.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our findings on the main issues in the case, the appeal must be allowed, the judgments and orders of the courts below annulling the usufructuary mortgage bond in question set aside and the transaction held binding on the estate of the insolvents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings h1-h5: exception applies.

precedents.citation: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta 1 , the matter was res judicata between the parties and the order of adjudication companyld be questioned only by an appeal against it, which had number been done. The learned Judge gave effect to that objection and held that the transferee was precluded from agitating the matter and that his only remedy was by way of appeal against the order of adjudication.

precedents.case_name: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: order of adjudication is res judicata between the parties and can only be questioned by appeal; transferee precluded from agitating in subsequent proceedings

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Mahomed Siddique YOUSUFs case 1 companyld number stand in the way of the appellant and that the entire companysideration of Rs. 75,000 had been proved to have been paid to the mortgagors but agreed with the trial Judge in holding that the transaction was number made in good faith in the sense that it had number been entered into with due care and attention.

precedents.case_name: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: order of adjudication stands in the way of transferee challenging it

precedents.citation: Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow 2

anchor.surface_text: Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow 2 , that upon a true companystruction of the Bankruptcy Ordinance of the Straits Settlements, s. 50, sub-s. 3 , which in terms is similar to the provisions of s. 35 of the Insolvency Regulation, the onus is upon the Official Assignee to prove that a companyveyance which he was seeking to set aside was number made in good faith and for valuable companysideration.

precedents.case_name: Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow
precedents.cited_proposition: onus is upon the Official Assignee to prove that a conveyance was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration
precedents.cited_holding: trial Judge misdirected on onus, requiring retrial

precedents.citation: Official Receiver v. P.L.K.M.R.M. Chettyar Firm 1

anchor.surface_text: Official Receiver v. P.L.K.M.R.M. Chettyar Firm 1 , which was a case under the Provincial Insolvency Act, 1920. On a companysideration of the provisions of s. 53 of the Act their Lordships reaffirmed the proposition laid down in the earlier case of that very year reported in Official Assignee Khoo. Saw Cheow 2 .

precedents.case_name: Official Receiver v. P.L.K.M.R.M. Chettyar Firm
precedents.cited_proposition: reaffirmed that onus lies on receiver under s.53 Provincial Insolvency Act similar to previous case

anchor.surface_text: Pope v. Official Assignee, Rangoon 3 . This case went up in appeal from a decision of the Rangoon High Court under the provisions of s. 55 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act. In this case their Lordships observed further that if the transaction impeached was a real and number fictitious one, the receiver companyld number be said to have brought the case within the section unless he proved that the transferee knew that the transferor was insolvent at the time the transfer was made, even though the transfer was of the entire assets of the transferor.

precedents.cited_proposition: for real transaction, receiver must prove transferee knew of transferor's insolvency

precedents.citation: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta 1 . That was an appeal from the Calcutta High Court in a case arising under the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, III of 1909. In that case the Judicial Committee, following the well established rule in England as laid down in the leading case of Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds 2 , has held that the order of adjudication based on the allegation that one of the several acts of insolvency was the impugned transfer was companyclusive against the transferee in subsequent proceedings taken by the Official Assignee to set aside the transfer by virtue of s. 116, sub-s. 2 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, 1909.

precedents.case_name: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: adjudication order conclusive against transferee in annulment proceedings under Presidency Towns Insolvency Act

precedents.citation: Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds 2

anchor.surface_text: Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds 2 , has held that the order of adjudication based on the allegation that one of the several acts of insolvency was the impugned transfer was companyclusive against the transferee in subsequent proceedings taken by the Official Assignee to set aside the transfer by virtue of s. 116, sub-s. 2 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, 1909.

precedents.case_name: Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds
precedents.cited_proposition: well established rule in England that adjudication order based on transfer as act of insolvency is conclusive against transferee

precedents.citation: Official Assignee of Madras v. O.R.M.O.R.S. Firm 1

anchor.surface_text: Official Assignee of Madras v. O.R.M.O.R.S. Firm 1 . Naturally very strong reliance was placed by the learned companynsel for the respondent-Receiver on that case.

precedents.case_name: Official Assignee of Madras v. O.R.M.O.R.S. Firm
precedents.cited_proposition: Madras High Court decision overruled by Privy Council

precedents.citation: Mohomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calculta 2

precedents.case_name: Mohomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: rule on res judicata from Presidency Towns Insolvency Act may not apply to Provincial/Regulation
